description: From Middle English *patten, alteration (with loss of medial l) of platten, pletten (“to pat”), from Old English plættan (“to buffet, strike, slap, smack, give a sounding blow”), from Proto-Germanic *plat- (“to strike, beat”), from Proto-Indo-European *blod-, *bled- (“to strike, beat”). Cognate with Middle Dutch platten, pletten (“to strike, bruise, crush, rub”), German platzen (“to split, burst, break up”), Bavarian patzen (“to pat”), Swedish plätta, pjätta (“to pat, tap”). For loss of l, compare patch for platch; pate for plate, etc. See plat.

adjectives.description: pat (comparative more pat, superlative most pat)

entries.meaning: Exactly suitable, fitting, apt; timely, convenient, opportune, ready for the occasion; especially of things spoken.
Trite, being superficially complete, lacking originality.

adverbs.description: pat (comparative more pat, superlative most pat)

entries.meaning: Opportunely, in a timely or suitable way.

examples: He has the routine down pat.

entries.meaning: The sound of a light slap or tap with a soft flat object, especially of a footstep
examples: We heard a pat on the door.

entries.meaning: A light tap or slap, especially with the hands
examples: Give Mary a pat on the shoulder to get her attention.

entries.meaning: A flattish lump of soft matter, especially butter or dung.

verbs.description: pat (third-person singular simple present pats, present participle patting, simple past and past participle patted)

entries.meaning: To (gently) tap the flat of one's hand on a person or thing.
examples: To show affection, he decided he would pat the boy on the head.

entries.meaning: To hit lightly and repeatedly with the flat of the hand to make smooth or flat
examples: I patted the cookie dough into shape.

entries.meaning: (UK, Australia, New Zealand) To stroke or fondle (an animal).
examples: Do you want to pat the cat?
